identificationModule.briefTitle: Hypothermia With Intrajugular Cooling in Acute Ischemic Stroke Thrombectomy
identificationModule.officialTitle: Safety and Tolerability of Intrajugular Cooling in Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke After Mechanical Thrombectomy

descriptionModule.briefSummary: Hypothermia with intrajugular cooling is a neuroprotective strategy that has been proven to minimize brain damage and maximize functional preservation in animal models of stroke. The purpose of this proof-of-concept study is to determine the safety and tolerability of intrajugular cooling in patients with acute ischemic stroke who are treated with mechanical thrombectomy.

armGroups.label: Intrajugular cooling group
armGroups.description: The safety and tolerability of hypothermia with intrajugular cooling will be investigated using 3+3 dose-escalation trial design.

interventions.name: Hypothermia with intrajugular cooling
interventions.description: Hypothermia with intrajugular cooling will be applied after successful recanalization of the culprit internal carotid artery/middle cerebral artery. The perfusion rate will be set at 30 ml/min. Low temperature saline will be infused into the internal jugular vein for 10 min, 15 min, 20 min, 25 min, and 30 min successively.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Number of participants with major response
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Within 24 hours after hypothermia with intrajugular cooling

ipdSharingStatementModule.description: Related data will be shared if full study protocol and statistical analysis plan are provided with reasonable design.
